Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Peri-operative Lidocaine for Radical Retropubic Prostatectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted at Austin and Box Hill hospitals.

Participants.evidence: We recruited 76 men scheduled for open retropubic radical prostatectomy.

Intervention.evidence: randomising them to receive either lidocaine 2% or saline 0.9%

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the efficacy of intra-operative intravenous lidocaine combined with a postoperative 24-hour subcutaneous lidocaine infusion in reducing pain and hospital stay after radical retropubic prostatectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative hospital stay.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We recruited 76 men scheduled for open retropubic radical prostatectomy

Number_Analysed.evidence: 75 participants were analysed (37 lidocaine, 38 saline) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Lidocaine reduced the postoperative hospital stay by a mean (95% CI) of 1.3 (0.3â€“2.4) days, p = 0.017.

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.
